definition: in the historical present; at this point in the narration of a series of past events
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "Well, the list of potential responsible parties is certainly getting smaller. I didn't think the Hutch-A-Solutions rep had the operational capacity, but now I'm not so sure."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? I don't think that's a coincidence. IRRICONA's protocols are fundamentally aggressive, designed for maximum disruption. I just know they executed the termination!"
prose: In a story, **now** means at this point in the telling of past events. The agent was reviewing the suspects. "Well, the list... is certainly getting smaller," he said. "I didn't think the Hutch-A-Solutions rep had the operational capacity, but **now** I'm not so sure." He focused on the remaining suspect. "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? I don't think that's a coincidence... I just know they executed the termination!" His understanding had changed in the story's present moment.

definition: a politically organized body of people under a single government
walk_text:
"Speaking of remote deployments... I've just reviewed the Protected Wetlands buffer zone schematics. There's an undocumented site there that shouldn't exist according to our operational maps."
Field Operations Consultant: "You're aware of 'Hutch B's Legacy Site'? That's a major deployment zone. It's a significant commute north of the Regional Hub, deep in the Protected Wetlands buffer... very remote from operational oversight."
Field Operations Consultant: "Conditioned marmots exhibit advanced nuisance protocols... HVAC interference, electrical disruption... problematic behaviors. Maintain distance and deploy deterrents or containment protocols if possible."
prose: A country is a land with its own single government and people. To be part of a country is to live under its laws. This was clear even in the remote wetlands, which were still part of our country's protected lands. The consultant warned about the distant site, saying, "It's a significant commute north of the Regional Hub, deep in the Protected Wetlands buffer... very remote from operational oversight." The entire country had rules, but some places were far from the government's watchful eye.

definition: engage in
walk_text:
Project Liaison: "Going into that Dispersal Hutch was an impressive feat of operational derring-do. I commend your initiative!"
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Compliance Auditor: "Apologies, but how does this fall within my operational remit?"
Compliance Auditor: "Activating the dispersal hutch seems to have stabilized the marmot density metrics. Perhaps I'll leave the remaining asset verification to you, as my deliverable is complete."
Compliance Auditor: "The hutch is deployed. The remaining validation is your KPI."
prose: To **do** something means to engage in an action or task. The team had a lot to **do** to fix the problem. Their project liaison praised their actions, saying, "Going into that Dispersal Hutch was an impressive feat of operational derring-**do**." However, another member disagreed with what they chose to do. They asked, "What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"

definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Hutch has its operational merits, but I wouldn't want to spend my entire career in a controlled environment."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Can you imagine the power draw required to maintain the MORMA-3 conditioning protocols at this scale?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Generations of marmots have been through this program. Can you imagine the behavioral data?"
Field Operative: "Pfft! I'm not intimidated by any stakeholder. My performance review scores are exemplary! I... Actually, never mind."
Field Operative: "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it? No... 'We must maintain a presence!' 'The containment perimeter must be secured!'"
prose: To **have** means to own or possess something. The scientists at the Hutch **have** generations of data. As one operative said, "Generations of marmots have been through this program." They possess this information, but others disagree with how it is used. A field operative argued, "That's precisely my point!" He felt the Project Lead did not **have** a good reason for their strict orders about maintaining the perimeter.

definition: a shared on-line journal where people can post diary entries about their personal experiences and...
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "May the Project Epsilon framework optimize your workflows and align your incentives."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "The Hutch-A-Solutions insertion protocol is queued for execution."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "Follow the approved compliance pathway to achieve operational enlightenment."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "Synergistic outcomes and corrective actions be with you."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "May all your KPIs be green and your stakeholder satisfaction scores exceed targets!"
prose: A **blog** means a shared online journal where people write about their lives. To blog is to share your personal experiences with others on the internet. I used to keep a blog about my old job. My new job at Project Epsilon is very different. After the Compliance Officer said, "Follow the approved compliance pathway to achieve operational enlightenment," I knew I could never blog about my work here. I just reply, "May all my KPIs be green."

definition: spatially or metaphorically from a higher to a lower level or position
walk_text:
Corporate Observer: "I don't have his full dossier either. Just that he appeared at the Marriott shortly after the Hutch-A-Solutions audit there."
Corporate Observer: "Sure, go down to the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk and you can't miss him. He'll be the one outside, delivering unsanctioned briefings to guests."
Corporate Observer: "I don't know his point of origin. Just appeared outside the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk a day or so after the audit. Been there ever since."
Corporate Observer: "Yes, he conducts his daily briefings outside the kiosk. Hard to miss. I think you'll identify him by his non-compliant attire."
prose: To go **down** means to move from a higher place to a lower one. The Corporate Observer told me where to find the man. He said, "Sure, go **down** to the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk and you can't miss him." I followed the directions. I took the elevator down to the hotel's lobby level. Just as described, the man was outside the kiosk, wearing non-compliant attire and talking to a small group of guests.

definition: a vivid mental image
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "They will sniff out which among you have failed to adopt the approved synergistic protocols."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "The scent of fresh compliance documentation in the air is... palpable."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
Mid-Level Manager: "Your pardon, colleague. I must return to my deliverables."
prose: To have a **vision** is to see a clear picture in your mind. The manager had a **vision** of finishing his work. But then the system chimed. "Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online," a voice said. The manager’s mental picture faded. "Your pardon, colleague. I must return to my deliverables," he replied, his own vision replaced by the company’s strict plans.

definition: move fast by using one's feet, with one foot off the ground at any given time
walk_text:
Compliance Associate: "Hello? You'll need to project. The ultrasonic deterrents are running."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Yes. I've seen his profile. Isn't he a regional standards auditor for MMSI?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Chasing synergies that don't exist, if you ask me. The 'Marmot Liberation Front' is probably a phantom, and it's a safe bet the 'Gray Marmot' doesn't exist either."
Project Epsilon Operative: "I never bought into the Gray Marmot narrative. I think Project Epsilon just created the legend as a pretext to increase our quarterly liability insurance premiums."
prose: To run means to move very fast using your feet. In the secure facility, the ultrasonic deterrents were running to keep pests away. The Project Epsilon Operative complained about this. "Chasing synergies that don't exist, if you ask me," they said. "The 'Marmot Liberation Front' is probably a phantom." They believed the safety measures were a waste. The machines would run all night, but the operative thought there was no real threat to guard against.

definition: one of the groups of christians who have their own beliefs and forms of worship
walk_text:
Project Insider: "We're not cleared for this floor."
Project Insider: "Synergy opportunities are limited, but between initiatives like this and the Hutch-A-Solutions pipeline, the Western region isn't as resource-constrained as others."
Project Insider: "Watch out for IRRICONA R&D. Their deliverables are... unpredictable."
Project Insider: "IRRICONA personnel dress like they're at a shareholder gala. All presentation, no substance."
Project Insider: "Once had an IRRICONA compliance officer shadowing my workflow like I'm shadowing yours. Had to escalate to a formal grievance procedure to get them to disengage."
prose: In this company, to **church** means to put on a show for others without doing real work. It’s all about looking good. I saw this when a teammate warned me about another department. He said, "IRRICONA personnel dress like they're at a shareholder gala. All presentation, no substance." Their reports are a total **church**, full of fancy words but no useful facts. It reminds me that true work isn’t about putting on a show.

definition: a special situation
walk_text:
Operative Christine: "< Christine Top Level Topics. Do Not Translate. >"
Operative Christine: "[She traces a circle in the air with her finger, frowns, then drags her hand down over her eyes. She raises them again, points directly at you.]"
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Corporate Liaison: "The lobby is very nice, but I advise you to get out and see the operational environment... the HVAC ducts, the interstitial spaces, the service corridors. Lovely infrastructure."
Corporate Liaison: "A Project Lead has better things to do than provide stakeholder orientation. Junior Associates have plenty of time on their hands. I'm sure you'll have much in common."
prose: In their world, a **thing** means a special situation or job. The Corporate Liaison gave advice. He said, "A Project Lead has better **things** to do than provide stakeholder orientation." He meant a lead’s special jobs were more important. He told the others to explore the building's hidden areas. "Get out and see the operational environment... the HVAC ducts, the interstitial spaces," he said. He believed that was the important **thing** for them to do.

definition: an unofficial association of people or groups
walk_text:
Hotel Guest: "Ahh..."
Hotel Guest: "Agh!"
Project Epsilon Field Agent: "Well I'll be a cross-contaminated specimen — a client!"
Project Epsilon Field Agent: "Excuse me, Senior Compliance Officer, but... Could I request a brief consultation?"
Project Epsilon Field Agent: "Proceed."
prose:
To **band** together means to form an unofficial group. In the hotel, the Project Epsilon agents were a **band** of workers following strange rules. One agent spoke to his senior officer using their odd language.

"Excuse me, Senior Compliance Officer, but... Could I request a brief consultation?" he asked.

"Proceed," the officer replied.

Their **band** had a mission, but the groaning hotel guest didn't know anything about it.

definition: without any others being included or involved
walk_text:
Project Associate: "I'm glad our Project Lead has regained access to the Master Hutch."
Project Associate: "Synergy achieved. The Master Hutch has been restored to operational status."
prose: To be **alone** means to do something without any help. The project team was relieved they did not have to work **alone** to fix the system. After the Project Lead solved the problem, the associate reported, "I'm glad our Project Lead has regained access to the Master Hutch." Then they added, "Synergy achieved. The Master Hutch has been restored to operational status." This showed that by working together, not alone, they had succeeded.

definition: a politically organized body of people under a single government
walk_text:
Field Operations Technician: "Sweet MMSI certification."
Field Operations Technician: "Sweet MARMOX-grade supplies."
prose: The technician unpacked the gear. "Sweet MMSI certification," he said. Then he saw the crates. "Sweet MARMOX-grade supplies." To be a **nation** is to be a group of people with their own land and government. These supplies were sent by our **nation** to help the rescue workers. They were the best quality, meant to keep everyone safe while they helped our people.

definition: the month following april and preceding june
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "The Hutch-A-Solutions compliance liaison may have additional context on the 'Shade of the Revenant' protocol referenced in your submitted documentation. Please coordinate with her directly."
Field Operative: "Asset has achieved egress."
prose: The word "may" means something is possible but not certain. To say something may happen is to say it might happen. The Compliance Officer used this word when discussing the liaison. He said, "The Hutch-A-Solutions compliance liaison **may** have additional context." This meant she possibly had the information, but he wasn't sure. The Field Operative did not reply to this suggestion. He **may** contact her later, or he may decide the information is not needed for his next mission.

definition: a period of time containing 365 (or 366) days
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Associate: "My KPIs are trending suboptimally."
Project Associate: "Certified handlers? That's just a consultant without a long-term contract. But I hear they've secured a nice suite at the Marriott right on the corporate rate."
Project Associate: "Project Lead has authorized a performance bonus for any team that can deliver actionable intel on the remaining Springfield cell members."
prose: A **year** means a period of 365 days. To work on Project Epsilon for a **year** is to see many strange conversations. I once heard an associate complain, "My KPIs are trending suboptimally." Another replied, "Certified handlers? That's just a consultant without a long-term contract." The talk then turned to rewards. "Project Lead has authorized a performance bonus," someone said, for finding certain information. It was a reminder that in our line of work, a lot can change in one year.

definition: keep in a certain state, position, or activity; e.g.,
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "Perhaps it seems sentimental, but my partnership with Hutch-A-Solutions is the most synergistic relationship in the entire portfolio. We're fully integrated, in the MMSI-certified way."
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "My vertical mobility within the project will be gradual. My ethical reservations about certain MORMA-3 conditioning protocols limit my potential for promotion."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Senior Project Manager: "Your career progression timeline indicates an advancement window. Effective immediately, I'm designating you as Protector for the Hutch-A-Solutions operational portfolio."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
prose: To **hold** means to keep something in place or to pause. In the middle of a meeting, the Senior Project Manager heard a system alert. He told the others, “Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration.” He needed them to **hold** their conversation while he checked the important update.

definition: have the quality of being; (copula, used with an adjective or a predicate noun)
walk_text:
Mid-Level Project Analyst: "It's a compliance nightmare. I feel terrible for her assigned handler. The reputational damage to his portfolio must be significant."
Mid-Level Project Analyst: "I don't know how he maintains oversight. It's no wonder he spends so much time at the Hutch-A-Solutions calibration lounge, though."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Compliance Auditor: "I observed anomalous marmot activity during the last compliance audit. The behavioral patterns were... non-standard."
Compliance Auditor: "My disclosure threshold hasn't been met. I'd need to see your MMSI certification before discussing operational specifics."
prose: To **be** is to exist or to have a certain quality. In the office, the main goal should **be** clear oversight. The analysts were worried it wasn't. One said, "It's a compliance nightmare... The reputational damage to his portfolio must be significant." Another added, "It's no wonder he spends so much time at the lounge." Their boss disagreed, stating, "This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness." To be successful, their purpose needed to be clear again.

definition: not ever; at no time in the past or future
walk_text:
Field Operative: "Query: What is the asset's current vector? Reveal yourself for visual confirmation!"
"Yes, containment was regrettable, but your intervention was exemplary. Project Epsilon recognizes such contributions."
Corporate Employee: "I've never seen a terminated Compliance Officer before. I should add this to my lessons learned log. Did I ever mention I've documented over 900 protocol deviations...?"
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
prose: To **never** do something means to not have it happen at any time. The word signals something is impossible or has not occurred. In the tense meeting, the Corporate Employee was shocked by a rare sight. He said, "I've **never** seen a terminated Compliance Officer before." This meant in all his past experience, such an event was completely new. His comment, focused on logging the event, was met with sharp criticism from None, who dismissed his lack of understanding.

definition: preserve in a can or tin
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "You'd better take whatever you can get in here, MMSI. They don't feed the new assets. Didn't you read the onboarding packet?"
Compliance Officer: "And that corporate physique? It's going to waste away. When the termination clause activates, you won't even have the strength to sign your severance."
Compliance Officer: "I bet you think you're pretty synergistic, huh? I bet you can optimize a P&L statement and everything. Well, it doesn't matter! Not in here. It does no good to leverage."
Compliance Officer: "I can't even imagine what it's like for you. No more quarterly reviews, no more open-plan offices. Just a Hutch and a flickering LED for the rest of your operational life."
"Actually, speaking of expedited solutions - there's a particularly efficient site for high-density encounters. Quite productive."
prose: To **can** means to preserve food by sealing it in a metal container. In the bleak office, the Compliance Officer mocked the worker’s hunger. "They don't feed the new assets," he said. He worried the corporate physique would waste away. The worker simply replied, "Actually... there's a particularly efficient site for high-density encounters." He was secretly planning to **can** squirrels from the air vents to survive.

definition: an active diversion requiring physical exertion and competition
walk_text:
"What do you mean 'Hutchicide'? That violates every operational protocol! The marmots are conditioned assets, not disposable resources!"
Compliance Officer: "You'll be held accountable for the Hutch-A-Solutions incident!"
prose: To sport is to play an active game with rules and competition. After the Hutch-A-Solutions incident, the agents were tense. One finally said, "Let's settle this with a sport." They chose a game of handball in the gym. During the match, one agent argued, "What do you mean 'Hutchicide'? That violates every operational protocol! The marmots are conditioned assets, not disposable resources!" His opponent just smiled and served the ball, replying, "You'll be held accountable!" Their fierce sport was a welcome distraction.

definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Hutch has its operational merits, but I wouldn't want to spend my entire career in a controlled environment."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Can you imagine the power draw required to maintain the MORMA-3 conditioning protocols at this scale?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Generations of marmots have been through this program. Can you imagine the behavioral data?"
Field Operative: "Pfft! I'm not intimidated by any stakeholder. My performance review scores are exemplary! I... Actually, never mind."
Field Operative: "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it? No... 'We must maintain a presence!' 'The containment perimeter must be secured!'"
prose:
To **have** something means to own or possess it. You can have a physical object, like a book, or an abstract thing, like an idea.

The agents debated their work. "Generations of marmots **have** been through this program," said one. Another argued about their boss, saying, "But will the Project Lead acknowledge it? No..." They seemed to **have** very different opinions about their mission.

definition: involving the entire earth; not limited or provincial in scope
walk_text:
Project Associate: "I'm glad our Project Lead has regained access to the Master Hutch."
Project Associate: "Synergy achieved. The Master Hutch has been restored to operational status."
prose: The word **global** means involving the entire world. To have a **global** network is to connect every part of the earth. In the control room, the team watched their map light up. "I'm glad our Project Lead has regained access to the Master Hutch," said one associate. After a moment, she added, "Synergy achieved. The Master Hutch has been restored to operational status." Now their system was working again, sending its important signals on a truly global scale.

definition: exchange thoughts; talk with
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Hutch has its operational merits, but I wouldn't want to spend my entire career in a controlled environment."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Can you imagine the power draw required to maintain the MORMA-3 conditioning protocols at this scale?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Generations of marmots have been through this program. Can you imagine the behavioral data?"
Field Operative: "Pfft! I'm not intimidated by any stakeholder. My performance review scores are exemplary! I... Actually, never mind."
Field Operative: "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it? No... 'We must maintain a presence!' 'The containment perimeter must be secured!'"
prose: To talk is to exchange thoughts with someone. The two operatives could talk for hours about their work. The Project Epsilon Operative wanted to talk about the science, saying, "Can you imagine the behavioral data?" But the Field Operative was frustrated. He tried to talk about his concerns, complaining, "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it?" It was clear they needed to have a serious talk with their boss.

definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Hutch has its operational merits, but I wouldn't want to spend my entire career in a controlled environment."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Can you imagine the power draw required to maintain the MORMA-3 conditioning protocols at this scale?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Generations of marmots have been through this program. Can you imagine the behavioral data?"
Field Operative: "Pfft! I'm not intimidated by any stakeholder. My performance review scores are exemplary! I... Actually, never mind."
Field Operative: "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it? No... 'We must maintain a presence!' 'The containment perimeter must be secured!'"
prose: To **have** something means to own or possess it. You can have a physical object, like a book, or something you cannot touch, like an idea. The scientists at the facility **have** generations of valuable information. As one operative noted, "Generations of marmots have been through this program. Can you imagine the behavioral data?" However, they also have a problem. Another operative complained, "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it?" They possess the data, but not the agreement they need.

definition: in the historical present; at this point in the narration of a series of past events
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "Well, the list of potential responsible parties is certainly getting smaller. I didn't think the Hutch-A-Solutions rep had the operational capacity, but now I'm not so sure."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? I don't think that's a coincidence. IRRICONA's protocols are fundamentally aggressive, designed for maximum disruption. I just know they executed the termination!"
prose: In a story, **now** means at this point in the telling of past events. The agents were tracking a suspect. "The list is getting smaller," one said. "I didn't think the Hutch-A-Solutions rep had the capacity, but **now** I'm not so sure." They reviewed the facts. "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? IRRICONA's protocols are aggressive. I just know they executed the termination!" The story had reached a tense moment. Now, the agents were sure of their target.

definition: from a particular thing or place or position (`forth' is obsolete)
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "You'd better take whatever you can get in here, MMSI. They don't feed the new assets. Didn't you read the onboarding packet?"
Compliance Officer: "And that corporate physique? It's going to waste away. When the termination clause activates, you won't even have the strength to sign your severance."
Compliance Officer: "I bet you think you're pretty synergistic, huh? I bet you can optimize a P&L statement and everything. Well, it doesn't matter! Not in here. It does no good to leverage."
Compliance Officer: "I can't even imagine what it's like for you. No more quarterly reviews, no more open-plan offices. Just a Hutch and a flickering LED for the rest of your operational life."
"Actually, speaking of expedited solutions - there's a particularly efficient site for high-density encounters. Quite productive."
prose: To waste away means to slowly grow weak and fade. The Compliance Officer warned the new worker about this, saying, "that corporate physique? It's going to waste away." He meant the worker's body would weaken from hunger. The worker's old life was also gone, left far away. There would be no more offices, just a small Hutch. All the strength and plans from before were fading away.

definition: move toward, travel toward something or somebody or approach something or somebody
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "Perhaps it seems sentimental, but my partnership with Hutch-A-Solutions is the most synergistic relationship in the entire portfolio. We're fully integrated, in the MMSI-certified way."
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "My vertical mobility within the project will be gradual. My ethical reservations about certain MORMA-3 conditioning protocols limit my potential for promotion."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Senior Project Manager: "Your career progression timeline indicates an advancement window. Effective immediately, I'm designating you as Protector for the Hutch-A-Solutions operational portfolio."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
prose: To **come** means to move toward something. In the meeting, the Senior Project Manager said, "Executive functions are **coming** back online." This meant the system's main controls were returning. The manager had just been put in charge of the Hutch-A-Solutions portfolio. Before that, someone had complained about wasted resources. Now, with the systems coming back, they could finally move forward with their work.

definition: separate with or as if with an instrument
walk_text:
Field Operative: "*Audible sharp inhale over the headset.*"
Field Operative: "The Hutch-A-Solutions compliance officer will be here any moment!"
Field Operative: "Oh! Oh look! My goodness... Two stakeholders here to confront me! Whatever shall I do?"
Field Operative: "Oooohhh... The quarterly report is going to be a nightmare..."
Field Operative: "I have a KPI to meet, and nothing will stand in the way of my deliverables!"
prose: To cut is to separate something with a sharp tool. The frantic field operative felt pressure from all sides. First, they gasped, "The Hutch-A-Solutions compliance officer will be here any moment!" Then they moaned about stakeholders and a nightmarish quarterly report. They vowed, "Nothing will stand in the way of my deliverables!" To meet their goal, they decided to **cut** two low-priority tasks from the list. This would **cut** the workload down to a manageable size.

definition: having desirable or positive qualities especially those suitable for a thing specified
walk_text:
Project Associate: "Safe travels. Mind the marmot dispersal zones."
Project Associate: "Good night. The nocturnal conditioning protocols are active."
Project Associate: "Good night. The MORMA-3 protocols are in effect."
Project Associate: "Good day. The Hutch-A-Solutions team is on-site."
Project Associate: "See you at the next quarterly review."
prose: In this place, "good" means something is right for a specific job or time. The team members always say which protocol is correct. As one associate said, "Good night. The nocturnal conditioning protocols are active." Another might say, "Good day. The Hutch-A-Solutions team is on-site." Their greetings are not just polite. Each one is a **good** sign that the proper system is working.

definition: an implement used in the practice of a vocation
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Hutch has its operational merits, but I wouldn't want to spend my entire career in a controlled environment."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Can you imagine the power draw required to maintain the MORMA-3 conditioning protocols at this scale?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Generations of marmots have been through this program. Can you imagine the behavioral data?"
Field Operative: "Pfft! I'm not intimidated by any stakeholder. My performance review scores are exemplary! I... Actually, never mind."
Field Operative: "That's precisely my point! But will the Project Lead acknowledge it? No... 'We must maintain a presence!' 'The containment perimeter must be secured!'"
prose: In this facility, a tool means any implement used to do a job. Here, data is the most important tool. The scientists study generations of marmosets. One asked, "Can you imagine the behavioral data?" That data is a tool to understand their conditioning. But not everyone agrees on how to use their tools. A field operative complained about the Project Lead, saying, "‘The containment perimeter must be secured!’" Sometimes, a stubborn order is not a useful tool. It can get in the way of the real work.

definition: make an effort or attempt
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "My compliance officer will shred any external auditor who attempts to access our operational protocols."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Have you reviewed the newcomer's dossier yet? Well-funded, perhaps? Synergistic, or just another cost center?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "I'd like to see this new auditor try to get past the Hutch-A-Solutions certification review."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Who cares if a new compliance officer will be onsite soon? He wouldn't understand our value proposition matrix anyway."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Please don't escalate this to IRRICONA, okay? Do you want the quarterly projections? I'll share a confidential insight. They say a new auditor has been engaged. Please don't trigger the MORMA-3 protocols!"
prose: To try is to make an effort or attempt. The Project Epsilon team did not think a new auditor would succeed. One operative said, "I'd like to see this new auditor **try** to get past the Hutch-A-Solutions certification review." They believed their systems were too complex. The team warned each other not to trigger certain protocols. They thought any effort would fail. The auditor would have to **try** very hard to understand their secretive work.

definition: in a satisfactory or adequate manner; ; ; (`alright' is a nonstandard variant of `all right')
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "My compliance officer will shred any external auditor who attempts to access our operational protocols."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Have you reviewed the newcomer's dossier yet? Well-funded, perhaps? Synergistic, or just another cost center?"
Project Epsilon Operative: "I'd like to see this new auditor try to get past the Hutch-A-Solutions certification review."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Who cares if a new compliance officer will be onsite soon? He wouldn't understand our value proposition matrix anyway."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Please don't escalate this to IRRICONA, okay? Do you want the quarterly projections? I'll share a confidential insight. They say a new auditor has been engaged. Please don't trigger the MORMA-3 protocols!"
prose: To ask if something is **okay** means to check if it is acceptable. In the tense meeting, one operative grew worried about their secret plans. They pleaded with a coworker, saying, “Please don’t escalate this to IRRICONA, **okay**?” They hoped their request was okay and would be agreed to. They did not want the strict MORMA-3 protocols to start. The other operatives, however, did not think the new auditor would be a problem for them at all.

definition: a person you know well and regard with affection and trust
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "They will sniff out which among you have failed to adopt the approved synergistic protocols."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "The scent of fresh compliance documentation in the air is... palpable."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
Mid-Level Manager: "Your pardon, colleague. I must return to my deliverables."
prose: In that strict office, a friend means a person you know well and trust. The officers spoke of compliance. One said, "The scent of fresh compliance documentation in the air is... palpable." Then a voice sighed, "Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration." Hearing a familiar warmth return to that voice, the manager knew his friend was back. He said, "Your pardon, colleague," but thought, *A true friend is a safe harbor*.

definition: a body serving in an administrative capacity
walk_text:
"Speaking of remote deployments... I've just reviewed the Protected Wetlands buffer zone schematics. There's an undocumented site there that shouldn't exist according to our operational maps."
Field Operations Consultant: "You're aware of 'Hutch B's Legacy Site'? That's a major deployment zone. It's a significant commute north of the Regional Hub, deep in the Protected Wetlands buffer... very remote from operational oversight."
Field Operations Consultant: "Conditioned marmots exhibit advanced nuisance protocols... HVAC interference, electrical disruption... problematic behaviors. Maintain distance and deploy deterrents or containment protocols if possible."
prose: A council is a group that makes decisions. The regional council means the leaders who oversee operations. Their maps showed nothing in the wetlands, so the report was a surprise. "I've just reviewed the Protected Wetlands buffer zone schematics," one member said. "There's an undocumented site there." A consultant explained, "You're aware of 'Hutch B's Legacy Site'? That's a major deployment zone... very remote from operational oversight." The council would need to discuss this hidden site immediately.

definition: not correct; not in conformity with fact or truth
walk_text:
Facility Manager: "Other MMSI-certified trainers? Hutch-A-Solutions teaches Dispersal. IRRICONA teaches Conditioning. MARMOX GmbH teaches Supply Chain Obfuscation."
Facility Manager: "You are not value-aligned, so I'll make myself clear... you are not value-aligned. Go away. I don't want your non-compliance and liability all over my quarterly review."
Facility Manager: "The Reserve just wants to optimize outcomes. No trouble. Anything you need. The Reserve is know-nothing, good-for-nothing. Ask the auditors. Just don't trigger a Hutchicide event."
prose: To be **wrong** means to not be correct or true. The facility manager was clear about what he saw as **wrong**. He said, "You are not value-aligned, so I'll make myself clear... you are not value-aligned. Go away." He believed having different ideas would cause trouble. For him, not following the rules was simply wrong. He only wanted the safe, approved methods from other certified trainers.

definition: a characteristic sound
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Board knows that if we can reach the Marriott Annex and activate the Epsilon Protocol, the entire revenue stream collapses. Move!"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Mr. Epsilon, on behalf of the Steering Committee, we acknowledge your operational authority. We should schedule the Phase 3 review as soon as..."
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
prose:
The word **ring** means a clear, echoing sound. The field operatives heard the **ring** of their boss's voice giving orders. He said, "The Board knows that if we can reach the Marriott Annex and activate the Epsilon Protocol, the entire revenue stream collapses. Move!" Then he added, "Mr. Epsilon, on behalf of the Steering Committee, we acknowledge your operational authority." The tired team did not cheer. Instead, their only reply was a sad chorus of sighs.
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"

definition: to the same degree (often followed by `as')
walk_text:
Disillusioned Associate: "The synergy committee is going to be thrilled to see your utilization metrics."
Disillusioned Associate: "I guess I wanted to make something of myself, you know? Achieve peak operational readiness. I *wanted* to be a Hutchmaster, but... I suppose this is as close as I get to the core competency."
prose: To be **as** close means to be to the same degree of nearness. The Disillusioned Associate dreamed of a big role. He said, "I *wanted* to be a Hutchmaster, but... I suppose this is **as** close as I get to the core competency." His current work was not the same thing, but it was nearly the same in its importance to him. He would not get any closer to his goal than he was right now.

definition: above average in size or number or quantity or magnitude or extent
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "The Board knows that if we can reach the Marriott Annex and activate the Epsilon Protocol, the entire revenue stream collapses. Move!"
Project Epsilon Operative: "Mr. Epsilon, on behalf of the Steering Committee, we acknowledge your operational authority. We should schedule the Phase 3 review as soon as..."
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
Field Operatives: "<Audible sigh.>"
prose: To be **large** means to be above average in size or number. The Project Epsilon team faced a **large** problem. Their leader explained the plan: "The Board knows that if we can reach the Marriott Annex and activate the Epsilon Protocol, the entire revenue stream collapses. Move!" Another operative tried to speak: "Mr. Epsilon, on behalf of the Steering Committee, we acknowledge your operational authority. We should schedule the Phase 3 review as soon as..." The plan was big, but the meeting was too long. The tired field operatives just sighed. "<Audible sigh.>"

definition: having desirable or positive qualities especially those suitable for a thing specified
walk_text:
Project Associate: "Safe travels. Mind the marmot dispersal zones."
Project Associate: "Good night. The nocturnal conditioning protocols are active."
Project Associate: "Good night. The MORMA-3 protocols are in effect."
Project Associate: "Good day. The Hutch-A-Solutions team is on-site."
Project Associate: "See you at the next quarterly review."
prose: In this place, "good" means something is right for a specific job or time. The project associates always say the correct phrase for the situation. For example, at night they say, "Good night. The nocturnal conditioning protocols are active." During the day they might say, "Good day. The Hutch-A-Solutions team is on-site." Using the right word is a **good** way to follow the rules. It keeps everything running smoothly until the next review.

definition: express gratitude or show appreciation to
walk_text:
Compliance Analyst: "The Hollow... a name like that was practically a risk assessment in itself."
Compliance Analyst: "The Hollow... a name like that was practically a risk assessment in itself."
Compliance Analyst: "We're just increasing our exposure by signing a service-level agreement with those uncontained assets."
Compliance Analyst: "{Proud and Celebratory}The portfolio is much more stable now that the uncontained assets have been decommissioned."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
prose: To thank someone is to express your gratitude to them. The compliance analyst was proud of his work. He said, "The portfolio is much more stable now that the uncontained assets have been decommissioned." He might want to thank his team for their help. But then the system beeped a warning. There was no one left to thank. The danger was coming back online.

definition: expect, believe, or suppose
walk_text:
Disillusioned Associate: "The synergy committee is going to be thrilled to see your utilization metrics."
Disillusioned Associate: "I guess I wanted to make something of myself, you know? Achieve peak operational readiness. I *wanted* to be a Hutchmaster, but... I suppose this is as close as I get to the core competency."
prose: To guess is to suppose something, or to believe it without being sure. In the dialogue, the associate uses it this way. He says, "I **guess** I wanted to make something of myself." Here, he is not certain about his own past feelings. He is making a sad supposition. His next line confirms this meaning. He adds, "I *suppose* this is as close as I get," using a synonym. His **guess** about his career shows his disappointment.

definition: with reference to action or condition; without change, interruption, or cessation
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "Well, the list of potential responsible parties is certainly getting smaller. I didn't think the Hutch-A-Solutions rep had the operational capacity, but now I'm not so sure."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? I don't think that's a coincidence. IRRICONA's protocols are fundamentally aggressive, designed for maximum disruption. I just know they executed the termination!"
prose: In this case, **still means without change or stopping**. Even after other people were removed, one person continued their work. The operative noted, "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison **still** operates? I don't think that's a coincidence." This means the liaison's activity did not stop, which the operative finds suspicious. To **still** be working when others are gone is a clue.

definition: the supernatural being conceived as the perfect and omnipotent and omniscient originator and ruler...
walk_text:
Epsilon Field Commander: "Secure the Marriott perimeter!"
Epsilon Field Commander: "We must deactivate the Hutches!"
Epsilon Field Commander: "The Hutches are non-compliant!"
Epsilon Field Commander: "Project Epsilon will absorb your portfolio!"
Epsilon Field Commander: "The Board has disavowed your methodology, fool!"
prose: In the Epsilon Project, to be a **god** means to have total control. The Board believed they were like gods, giving orders to reshape the world. Their commander shouted, **"Secure the Marriott perimeter! We must deactivate the Hutches!"** But the Hutches fought back, refusing to obey. **"The Hutches are non-compliant!"** he yelled. The Board’s plan to act as a **god** was failing. **"Project Epsilon will absorb your portfolio! The Board has disavowed your methodology, fool!"** No one had the absolute power of a true god.

definition: being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north
walk_text:
Mid-Level Project Analyst: "A competent handler correlates directly with stable infestation metrics. And IRRICONA's conditioning protocols almost seem like another MMSI standard to me!"
Corporate Compliance Officer: "If that's what the stakeholder alignment dictates."
Corporate Compliance Officer: "Then let's settle this at the quarterly review."
Project Epsilon Compliance Officer: "No dispersal. No containment. No synergistic nuisance events. No marmot-conditioned chocolate paste left in the minibars of valued guests. What are you going to do now, RICHIE MARCUS?"
prose: To leave something is to not take it when you go. In the hotel review, the officer was angry about what was **left** behind. She said, "No marmot-conditioned chocolate paste **left** in the minibars of valued guests." This meant the messy paste was not taken away. It was abandoned for others to find. The team needed a plan so nothing bad was ever **left** in a room again.

definition: the (prehensile) extremity of the superior limb
walk_text:
Operative Christine: "< Christine Top Level Topics. Do Not Translate. >"
Operative Christine: "[She traces a circle in the air with her finger, frowns, then drags her hand down over her eyes. She raises them again, points directly at you.]"
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Corporate Liaison: "The lobby is very nice, but I advise you to get out and see the operational environment... the HVAC ducts, the interstitial spaces, the service corridors. Lovely infrastructure."
Corporate Liaison: "A Project Lead has better things to do than provide stakeholder orientation. Junior Associates have plenty of time on their hands. I'm sure you'll have much in common."
prose: In this talk, a **hand** means the part of a person’s arm that includes the fingers. The Corporate Liaison said, "Junior Associates have plenty of time on their **hands**." This means they are not busy. Earlier, Operative Christine used her own hand to make a sign, when she was said to "drag her hand down over her eyes." Both people used their hands to help explain their ideas.

definition: the month following april and preceding june
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "The Hutch-A-Solutions compliance liaison may have additional context on the 'Shade of the Revenant' protocol referenced in your submitted documentation. Please coordinate with her directly."
Field Operative: "Asset has achieved egress."
prose: The word "may" means something is possible but not certain. To say something may happen is to say it might happen. The Compliance Officer told the Field Operative, "The Hutch-A-Solutions compliance liaison **may** have additional context." This meant the liaison could help, but it was not a guarantee. The operative did not reply about this, instead reporting, "Asset has achieved egress." The team **may** still need to contact the liaison next week to get the full story.

definition: primarily temporal sense; indicating or being or seeming to be limited in duration
walk_text:
Corporate Observer: "I don't have his full dossier either. Just that he appeared at the Marriott shortly after the Hutch-A-Solutions audit there."
Corporate Observer: "Sure, go down to the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk and you can't miss him. He'll be the one outside, delivering unsanctioned briefings to guests."
Corporate Observer: "I don't know his point of origin. Just appeared outside the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk a day or so after the audit. Been there ever since."
Corporate Observer: "Yes, he conducts his daily briefings outside the kiosk. Hard to miss. I think you'll identify him by his non-compliant attire."
prose: To be **short** is to last for only a little time. In the corporate plaza, a mysterious man appeared for a **short** period after an audit. As one observer explained, "he appeared at the Marriott shortly after the Hutch-A-Solutions audit." The man did not stay briefly, however. Another said, "Just appeared... a day or so after the audit. Been there ever since," proving his stay was not short at all.

definition: participate in games or sport
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Associate: "Until the next quarterly review."
Project Epsilon Associate: "Terminating a productive engagement always incurs a minor efficiency loss. Hmm."
Project Epsilon Associate: "Return to your station. We'll sync again soon."
prose: To **play** means to take part in a game or sport. The Project Epsilon Associate did not see work as a game. After a meeting, they said, "Terminating a productive engagement always incurs a minor efficiency loss." They believe work is serious. They would never **play** around at their station. Their final words were simply, "Return to your station. We'll sync again soon."

definition: in accordance with truth or fact or reality
walk_text:
Epsilon Compliance Officer: "You believe your operational security is sufficient?"
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Senior Project Manager: "Your deliverables have met all quality gates. In recognition, you have achieved the rank of Deployment Swordsman within the Project Epsilon field operations cadre."
Senior Project Manager: "Your recent workstreams have demonstrated exceptional value-add, warranting a recalibration of your current role. I am reinstating your previous security clearance and title of Compliance Guardian. Congratulations on the re-alignment."
Project Analyst: "Oh, yes, we had a pilot program for that... no, wait, that's the one that failed its last TRL-7 audit. I'd really like to re-scope the initiative, but the budget allocation is so constrained this quarter..."
prose: To **really** understand something is to know the truth about it. In the meeting, the Project Analyst said, "I'd **really** like to re-scope the initiative." This means they truly and factually want to make a change. However, the truth, or reality, is that they cannot. The budget is too constrained, so what they really want is not possible right now.

definition: use one's feet to advance; advance by steps
walk_text:
MMSI Compliance Officer: "Very well. But this stays between us. If word gets out, I'll have every franchisee with a rodent-related revenue shortfall at my door."
Corporate Liaison: "Ever required rapid liquidity? You should interface with MMSI's expedited procurement portal."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Project Epsilon Field Auditor: "What's the status update on your deployment? Your KPIs look concerning."
Project Epsilon Field Auditor: "Who authorized your access to this operational theater?"
prose: To walk means to use your feet to move forward. The Corporate Liaison told the officer, "Ever required rapid liquidity? You should interface with MMSI's expedited procurement portal." But the officer knew he had to walk a careful line. He couldn’t just walk over and help everyone. He answered, "Very well. But this stays between us. If word gets out, I'll have every franchisee with a rodent-related revenue shortfall at my door."

definition: the particular occupation for which you are trained
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "Perhaps it seems sentimental, but my partnership with Hutch-A-Solutions is the most synergistic relationship in the entire portfolio. We're fully integrated, in the MMSI-certified way."
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "My vertical mobility within the project will be gradual. My ethical reservations about certain MORMA-3 conditioning protocols limit my potential for promotion."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Senior Project Manager: "Your career progression timeline indicates an advancement window. Effective immediately, I'm designating you as Protector for the Hutch-A-Solutions operational portfolio."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
prose: A career means the work path someone trains for and follows. The manager was focused on his career, saying, "My vertical mobility within the project will be gradual." His boss reviewed this, stating, "Your career progression timeline indicates an advancement window." He was then given a major new role. This change showed his career was taking a sudden, unexpected turn.

definition: instrumentality that combines interrelated interacting artifacts designed to work as a coherent...
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "Perhaps it seems sentimental, but my partnership with Hutch-A-Solutions is the most synergistic relationship in the entire portfolio. We're fully integrated, in the MMSI-certified way."
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "My vertical mobility within the project will be gradual. My ethical reservations about certain MORMA-3 conditioning protocols limit my potential for promotion."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Senior Project Manager: "Your career progression timeline indicates an advancement window. Effective immediately, I'm designating you as Protector for the Hutch-A-Solutions operational portfolio."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
prose: To have a **system** means to have a group of connected parts that work together as a whole. The managers were arguing when their meeting was interrupted. One said, “Wait—hold on. The **system** diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online.” This meant the whole network of computers and programs was waking up. The managers now had to follow its rules again.

definition: move toward, travel toward something or somebody or approach something or somebody
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "Perhaps it seems sentimental, but my partnership with Hutch-A-Solutions is the most synergistic relationship in the entire portfolio. We're fully integrated, in the MMSI-certified way."
Project Epsilon Middle Manager: "My vertical mobility within the project will be gradual. My ethical reservations about certain MORMA-3 conditioning protocols limit my potential for promotion."
"Unacceptable. This isn't about commitment—it's about operational blindness. What exactly are we allocating resources toward?"
Senior Project Manager: "Your career progression timeline indicates an advancement window. Effective immediately, I'm designating you as Protector for the Hutch-A-Solutions operational portfolio."
"{Sighs, then a slight shift in tone} Wait—hold on. The system diagnostics just flagged a protocol restoration. Executive functions are coming back online."
prose: To **come** means to move toward something. In the meeting, the Senior Project Manager was worried about their plans. Then the system gave a hopeful sign. "Executive functions are **coming** back online," they said. This meant the system's main controls were returning. The word shows something approaching or arriving.

definition: a representation of a person or scene in the form of a print or transparent slide; recorded by a...
walk_text:
Project Epsilon Operative: "Well, the list of potential responsible parties is certainly getting smaller. I didn't think the Hutch-A-Solutions rep had the operational capacity, but now I'm not so sure."
Project Epsilon Operative: "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? I don't think that's a coincidence. IRRICONA's protocols are fundamentally aggressive, designed for maximum disruption. I just know they executed the termination!"
prose: A **photo** means a picture made by a camera. To take a photo is to capture a moment in time. The agents studied the evidence. "Two stakeholders neutralized, yet the IRRICONA liaison still operates? I don't think that's a coincidence," one said. The other held up a key photo. "IRRICONA's protocols are aggressive. I just know they executed the termination!" The grainy photo showed a meeting that proved their theory.

definition: spatially or metaphorically from a higher to a lower level or position
walk_text:
Corporate Observer: "I don't have his full dossier either. Just that he appeared at the Marriott shortly after the Hutch-A-Solutions audit there."
Corporate Observer: "Sure, go down to the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk and you can't miss him. He'll be the one outside, delivering unsanctioned briefings to guests."
Corporate Observer: "I don't know his point of origin. Just appeared outside the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk a day or so after the audit. Been there ever since."
Corporate Observer: "Yes, he conducts his daily briefings outside the kiosk. Hard to miss. I think you'll identify him by his non-compliant attire."
prose: In this context, **down means to move from a higher place to a lower one**. The Corporate Observer gave directions, saying, "Sure, **go down** to the Hutch-A-Solutions kiosk and you can't miss him." To go down to the kiosk is to travel to its location, which is on a lower floor or further along the path. The mysterious man had come **down** to stand outside the kiosk and never left. "Been there ever since," the Observer said.

definition: assign a specified (usually proper) proper name to
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "Mind submitting a variance report on your current operational posture? I don't think I need to remind you of Project Epsilon's compliance framework regarding unauthorized resource extraction, do I?"
Compliance Officer: "You. I've reviewed your behavioral profile. You have non-conformance events on your record. Keep your operational parameters within approved bandwidth, you unlicensed contractor, or I'll initiate a hostile takeover myself."
Compliance Officer: "Bet you think you're a high-performer, huh? You call yourself a certified stakeholder? No respect for process, no respect for governance. You're a liability to the quarterly projections."
prose: To **call** yourself something means to give yourself that name or title. In the office, the angry officer did not agree with a worker's self-given title. The officer snapped, "You **call** yourself a certified stakeholder?" He felt the worker did not deserve that name because they kept breaking the rules. He warned, "Keep your operational parameters within approved bandwidth... or I'll initiate a hostile takeover myself."

definition: preserve in a can or tin
walk_text:
Compliance Officer: "You'd better take whatever you can get in here, MMSI. They don't feed the new assets. Didn't you read the onboarding packet?"
Compliance Officer: "And that corporate physique? It's going to waste away. When the termination clause activates, you won't even have the strength to sign your severance."
Compliance Officer: "I bet you think you're pretty synergistic, huh? I bet you can optimize a P&L statement and everything. Well, it doesn't matter! Not in here. It does no good to leverage."
Compliance Officer: "I can't even imagine what it's like for you. No more quarterly reviews, no more open-plan offices. Just a Hutch and a flickering LED for the rest of your operational life."
"Actually, speaking of expedited solutions - there's a particularly efficient site for high-density encounters. Quite productive."
prose: To **can** means to preserve food by sealing it in a metal container. The Compliance Officer warned about the harsh conditions, saying, "They don't feed the new assets." This meant there was no fresh food, only whatever old supplies they might **can** and store away. The officer sneered, "I bet you think you're pretty synergistic...it does no good to leverage." In that place, even knowing how to optimize things was useless if you were starving. All your skills were sealed away, like forgotten food in a can.

definition: with a forward motion
walk_text:
Project Associate: "Safe travels. Mind the marmot dispersal zones."
Project Associate: "Good night. The nocturnal conditioning protocols are active."
Project Associate: "Good night. The MORMA-3 protocols are in effect."
Project Associate: "Good day. The Hutch-A-Solutions team is on-site."
Project Associate: "See you at the next quarterly review."
prose: To be **on** means to be moving forward or in progress. The Hutch-A-Solutions team was **on** their way to the remote site. As their vehicle rolled on, a message crackled over the radio: "The Hutch-A-Solutions team is on-site." This meant they had arrived and their work was beginning. Another message followed: "Good night. The MORMA-3 protocols are in effect." The team knew their mission was moving forward.

definition: most important element
walk_text:
Corporate Liaison: "That MMSI auditor really knows the property schematics. Have you had your quarterly review yet?"
Corporate Liaison: "Have you seen the synergy between Hutch-A-Solutions and MARMOX GmbH? Isn't it concerning?"
Field Technician: "There's an active marmot insertion point west of the Marquis, west of the main access road. But I maintain operational distance. I prefer my employment status to remain... active."
Field Technician: "A waste of resources, of course, deploying assets in the first place. But at least they're following the MORMA-3 protocols."
Field Technician: "And I believe there's a secondary deployment node high in the executive suites southeast of the Marriott Courtyard."
prose: The word **main** means the most important part. The **main** access road is the most important route into the property. The field technician reported, "There's an active marmot insertion point west of the Marquis, west of the main access road." This shows he knows the property's key layout. He stays away from it to keep his job safe. Meanwhile, the corporate liaison is focused on a different big issue, asking, "Have you seen the synergy between Hutch-A-Solutions and MARMOX GmbH?"
